articles.headline: Success Without Ads
articles.snippet: Consumer Reports, a monthly magazine, continues to thrive with a subscription-only model, even on the Web.
articles.abstract: Consumer Reports, a monthly magazine, continues to thrive with a subscription-only model, even on the Web.
articles.lead_paragraph: YONKERS  It makes no sense for publications to charge readers on the Web  at least, that’s the conventional wisdom. But conventional wisdom does not carry much weight at Consumer Reports, that detailed guide to buying everything from prescription drugs to pickup trucks.

articles.headline: 6 Arrested Over Plots to Pump Up Share Prices
articles.snippet: What began with an undercover F.B.I. agent’s posing as a corrupt hedge fund manager led to the arrest of six people  on charges of fraud in the shadowy world of penny stocks.
articles.abstract: What began with an undercover F.B.I. agent’s posing as a corrupt hedge fund manager led to the arrest of six people  on charges of fraud in the shadowy world of penny stocks.
articles.lead_paragraph: What began with an undercover F.B.I. agent’s posing as a corrupt hedge fund manager led to the indictments of six people yesterday on charges of fraud in the shadowy world of penny stocks, federal prosecutors said.

articles.headline: Gold’s Quirk: It’s Volatile, but Holders Feel Secure
articles.snippet: Gold has a long history of waxing and waning in allure. At the moment, it holds a particular attraction, given fears of  inflation, the risks in the financial market and the falling value of the dollar.
articles.abstract: Gold has a long history of waxing and waning in allure. At the moment, it holds a particular attraction, given fears of  inflation, the risks in the financial market and the falling value of the dollar.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Nov. 7, the market price of a troy ounce of gold bullion briefly touched $845.50, the top so far in gold’s current eight-year bull market and a 28-year high in New York trading. The news made headlines and became a hot topic on radio talk shows.

articles.headline: Slowing Job Growth Seen as Ominous Sign for Economy
articles.snippet: The employment picture offered assurance that the economy was not plummeting, but the Federal Reserve may feel less pressure to aggressively ease interest rates.
articles.abstract: The employment picture offered assurance that the economy was not plummeting, but the Federal Reserve may feel less pressure to aggressively ease interest rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation gained a modest 94,000 jobs in November, the Labor Department reported yesterday, pulling back considerably from the previous month in the clearest sign yet that the American economy was headed for a substantial slowdown.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: From ‘Troubled’ to ‘Killer,’ Despite Many Efforts
articles.snippet: Robert A. Hawkins made a five-year journey through a maze of juvenile services before killing eight people and himself in a mall.
articles.abstract: Robert A. Hawkins made a five-year journey through a maze of juvenile services before killing eight people and himself in a mall.
articles.lead_paragraph: OMAHA, Dec. 7  “As the twig is bent, so grows the tree.” A sign bearing these severe but hopeful words marks the entrance to Cooper Village, a residential treatment facility for teenagers along the rural northern edge of Omaha.

articles.headline: Trucks Power China’s Economy, at a Suffocating Cost
articles.snippet: Every night, columns of hulking freight trucks invade China’s major cities with a reverberating roar and dark clouds of diesel exhaust so thick it dims headlights.
articles.abstract: Every night, columns of hulking freight trucks invade China’s major cities with a reverberating roar and dark clouds of diesel exhaust so thick it dims headlights.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China  Every night, columns of hulking blue and red freight trucks invade China’s major cities with a reverberating roar of engines and dark clouds of diesel exhaust so thick it dims headlights.

articles.headline: The Pursuit of Justice, or Money?
articles.snippet: In some cases, litigation can look more like a racket for income redistribution than a search for fairness.
articles.abstract: In some cases, litigation can look more like a racket for income redistribution than a search for fairness.
articles.lead_paragraph: “If I don’t bring the lead paint industry to its knees in three years, I will give them my boat.”

articles.headline: Clinton Proudly Talks of Scars While Keeping Her Guard Up
articles.snippet: After years of public battles, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton must prove she is not too hardened to inspire.
articles.abstract: After years of public battles, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton must prove she is not too hardened to inspire.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  In July 2000, Hillary Clinton stood on a stage at the University of Arkansas and struggled to keep her composure. Her voice was unusually soft that day, her words seemingly unfiltered.

articles.headline: Court Intrigue for the King of Torts
articles.snippet: Richard Scruggs, the lawyer who helped win huge verdicts on behalf of smokers and victims of Hurricane Katrina, is fighting charges that he tried to bribe a judge.
articles.abstract: Richard Scruggs, the lawyer who helped win huge verdicts on behalf of smokers and victims of Hurricane Katrina, is fighting charges that he tried to bribe a judge.
articles.lead_paragraph: Clarksdale, Miss.

articles.headline: How to Solve a Subprime Mess? An Iowan Says, Let’s Caucus
articles.snippet: Iowa’s attorney general is trying to stem a surge of foreclosures by cajoling mortgage servicing companies to modify loans before borrowers fall too far behind.
articles.abstract: Iowa’s attorney general is trying to stem a surge of foreclosures by cajoling mortgage servicing companies to modify loans before borrowers fall too far behind.
articles.lead_paragraph: A HALF-DOZEN years before subprime mortgages were on the national agenda, Tom Miller, the attorney general of Iowa, led teams of state officials from around the country in negotiating settlements totaling more than $800 million with two large home lenders that were accused of misleading and overcharging borrowers.

articles.headline: Sharper Claws for Recovering Executive Pay
articles.snippet: A standard when pay has been based on short-lived earnings.
articles.abstract: A standard when pay has been based on short-lived earnings.
articles.lead_paragraph: INVESTORS everywhere should applaud the deal struck last week by the UnitedHealth Group to recover nearly $1 billion in pay from former executives involved in the company’s option backdating mess.

articles.headline: Parole Case and  ’90s AIDS View Trail Huckabee
articles.snippet: Mike Huckabee is facing scrutiny over a rapist’s parole and his past support for quarantining people with AIDS.
articles.abstract: Mike Huckabee is facing scrutiny over a rapist’s parole and his past support for quarantining people with AIDS.
articles.lead_paragraph: As new polls highlight Mike Huckabee’s ascent in the Republican presidential field, he is drawing new scrutiny of his record in Arkansas, particularly his actions in the release of a convicted rapist who went on to murder a woman and his response to a questionnaire in which he said people with AIDS should be quarantined.

articles.headline: Oil-Rich Nations Use More Energy, Cutting Exports
articles.snippet: Several nations that are large suppliers may start importing oil within a decade, adding strains to the global market.
articles.abstract: Several nations that are large suppliers may start importing oil within a decade, adding strains to the global market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economies of many big oil-exporting countries are growing so fast that their need for energy within their borders is crimping how much they can sell abroad, adding new strains to the global oil market.

articles.headline: As Iraqis Vie for Kirkuk’s Oil, Kurds Are Pawns
articles.snippet: Some 2,200 squatters have turned the Kirkuk soccer stadium into a refugee city as they wait to vote on Kurdish regional rule.
articles.abstract: Some 2,200 squatters have turned the Kirkuk soccer stadium into a refugee city as they wait to vote on Kurdish regional rule.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIRKUK, Iraq  Even by the skewed standards of a country where millions are homeless or in exile, the squalor of the Kirkuk soccer stadium is a startling sight.

articles.headline: Disability Cases Last Longer as Backlog Rises
articles.snippet: Lengthening delays in the resolution of Social Security disability claims have left thousands of people in limbo.
articles.abstract: Lengthening delays in the resolution of Social Security disability claims have left thousands of people in limbo.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C.  Steadily lengthening delays in the resolution of Social Security disability claims have left hundreds of thousands of people in a kind of purgatory, now waiting as long as three years for a decision.

articles.headline: Republican Candidates Firm on Immigration
articles.snippet: The candidates told Spanish-language viewers that they would take a hard line on illegal immigration.
articles.abstract: The candidates told Spanish-language viewers that they would take a hard line on illegal immigration.
articles.lead_paragraph: CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 9  In front of what will probably be their most pro-immigration audience, Republican candidates toned down their rhetoric but told Spanish-language television viewers in a debate on Sunday that they would take strong measures to close off the country’s borders to illegal immigration.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Marc Santora

articles.headline: Big Banks Scale Back Plan to Aid in Debt Crisis
articles.snippet: Some of the country’s largest banks are scaling back a plan to calm the debt markets, making the new superfund look increasingly irrelevant.
articles.abstract: Some of the country’s largest banks are scaling back a plan to calm the debt markets, making the new superfund look increasingly irrelevant.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the country’s largest banks are scaling back a plan set in motion by the Treasury Department to shore up troubled investment vehicles and calm the debt markets.

articles.headline: Unlikely Ally Against Congo Republic Graft
articles.snippet: Western investors are suing the Congo Republic to recover old debts that they bought for pennies on the dollar.
articles.abstract: Western investors are suing the Congo Republic to recover old debts that they bought for pennies on the dollar.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRAZZAVILLE, the Congo Republic  The main teaching hospital here is in such disrepair that many patients have to pay freelance porters for piggyback rides up and down the stairs to get X-rays. It costs $2 a flight, each way.

articles.headline: Muckraking Pays, Just Not in Profit
articles.snippet: Amid the financial pressures facing the newspaper industry, investigative journalism has been hit hard.
articles.abstract: Amid the financial pressures facing the newspaper industry, investigative journalism has been hit hard.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Friday, the city of Chicago agreed to pay out $20 million to settle lawsuits filed by four former death-row inmates who said they had been tortured by police officers and subsequently wrongly convicted. The four men were among dozens of black men who said they were tortured, beaten with phone books and suffocated with plastic typewriter covers while in police custody in the 1970s and 1980s, according to special prosecutors.

articles.headline: A Crime Buster, With His Eye on the Future
articles.snippet: Rudolph W. Giuliani plainly displayed the rawness of his promise and drive as U.S. attorney in the 1980s.
articles.abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani plainly displayed the rawness of his promise and drive as U.S. attorney in the 1980s.
articles.lead_paragraph: He was, to the popular eye, Eliot Ness reincarnated, an unsparing prosecutor for a crime-shadowed age. And when the United States attorney in Manhattan resigned in January 1989, he earned a tabloid salute:

articles.headline: Slot Machines for the Young and Active
articles.snippet: A new class of slot machines, aimed at attracting younger players who grew up with video games, is demanding something more than the ability to pull a lever — skill.
articles.abstract: A new class of slot machines, aimed at attracting younger players who grew up with video games, is demanding something more than the ability to pull a lever — skill.
articles.lead_paragraph: The venerable slot machine is undergoing a generational shift. For more than a century, since its invention by a German immigrant named Charles Fey in the 1890s, slot machines have required little more than cash, faith and an ability to pull a lever or push a button.

articles.headline: Screenwriters Dig In for an Extended Brawl
articles.snippet: The latest round of talks has blown up over issues that had been buried inside the writers’ contract proposals.
articles.abstract: The latest round of talks has blown up over issues that had been buried inside the writers’ contract proposals.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9  Eight months ago, in a contemplative moment, Patric M. Verrone, president of the Writers Guild of America West, sketched out what could have been a script for the collision that wrecked talks between Hollywood’s producers and striking writers on Friday.

articles.headline: Nokia Pushes to Regain U.S. Sales in Spite of Apple and Google
articles.snippet: Although it is the largest handset maker in the world, Nokia has languished in the American market, hurt by its refusal to adapt its strategy to the market’s idiosyncrasies.
articles.abstract: Although it is the largest handset maker in the world, Nokia has languished in the American market, hurt by its refusal to adapt its strategy to the market’s idiosyncrasies.
articles.lead_paragraph: ESPOO, Finland  When Google announced plans in October to revolutionize the software of cellular phones, few were more eager to hear the details than the industry veterans at Nokia. They still are.
